newsitem.title: UK: Western oil refiners see healthy margins trimmed.
newsitem.headline: Western oil refiners see healthy margins trimmed.

text.p: Western oil refiners had healthy profit margins trimmed last week but in Singapore margins recovered from recent lows, according to Reuters data using standard product yields.
In the West, faltering gasoline hit refinery margins hard but they were still holding well above the average level of the past six months.
In Rotterdam, complex refiners were making $2.21 a barrel refining Brent last Friday, below the $2.55 average of the past three weeks but above the $1.65 six month average.
Gasoline and gas oil both lost about 80 cents a barrel compared to Brent crude last week while heavy fuel fell a more modest 25 cents a barrel.
Dealers expect another soft week on gasoline in Europe which could add further downward pressure on margins.
In the Mediterranean, there were similar losses on oil products against Urals crude.
A complex refiner in Italy now makes $1.88 a barrel processing Urals crude compared to an average of $1.61 over the past six months. But three weeks ago margins hit a peak of over $3.50 a barrel.
On the US gulf coast, refiners processing Brent made about $1.30 a barrel last week, sharply down from levels seen at the start of June.
Margins have averaged $1.12 over the past six months, hitting a peak of $3.21 in early April.
Last week's drop in margins reflected a drop of more than $1 a barrel in the value of gasoline compared to Brent. Heating oil and residual fuel also fell against Brent but by lesser amounts.
In Singapore, refiners saw a modest bounce from recently weak profit margins.
Complex refiners made $2.92 a barrel running Dubai crude last Friday compared to levels around $2.65 over the past three weeks.
Despite the gain, margins remain sharply depressed compared to levels over the past six months which averaged $3.90 a barrel and peaked at well over $6 in April.
